---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [75c391a44b](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17587/commits/75c391a44bc7881558216ea8b29d91b741be5d81)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Data.Sym.Sym2 | 447 | 449 | +2 (+0.45%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
|<details><summary>8 files</summary> `Mathlib.Data.Multiset.Sym` `Mathlib.SetTheory.Game.Basic` `Mathlib.SetTheory.Game.Impartial` `Mathlib.SetTheory.Game.PGame` `Mathlib.Order.GameAdd` `Mathlib.Data.Sym.Sym2` `Mathlib.Data.List.Sym` `Mathlib.Data.Sym.Sym2.Order`</details>|2|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ card_filter_mem_of_mem_edgeFinset`
`+ card_filter_mem_of_mem_edgeSet`
`+ card_toFinset_le_two`
`+ card_toFinset_mk_of_ne`
`+ card_toFinset_of_isDiag`
`+ card_toFinset_of_mem_edgeFinset`
`+ card_toFinset_of_mem_edgeSet`
`+ card_toFinset_of_not_isDiag`
`+ coe_mk_eq`
`+ coe_toFinset`
`+ exists_eq`
`+ instance : Coe (Sym2 α) (Finset α) := ⟨Sym2.toFinset⟩`
`+ instance : Coe (Sym2 α) (Multiset α) := ⟨Sym2.toMultiset⟩`
`+ isDiag_iff_exists`
`+ mem_toFinset`
`+ not_isDiag_iff_exists`
`+ one_le_card_toFinset`
`+ setOf_mem_eq`
`+ toFinset`
`+ toFinset_eq`
`+ toFinset_mk`
`+ toFinset_toMultiset`
`+ toMultiset`
`+ toMultiset_mk`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
I just noticed that there is both the file Mathlib.Data.Sym.Sym2.lean and the folder Mathlib.Data.Sym.Sym2. Is this intended or should the contents of Sym2.lean eventualy migrate into the folder?
I removed the definition of Sym2.card because it was causing some conflicts that I don't quite understand

I'll take a look @FordUniver. For Sym2 organization, it used to all be in one file, and I think it's sort of been partially refactored. Maybe it would make sense to move Sym2.lean to Sym2/Basic.lean in a future PR.

Here's what your degree-sum proof looks like so far @FordUniver.
```lean
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.BigOperators.Ring.Finset
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.Enumerative.DoubleCounting

variable {α : Type*} [Fintype α] [DecidableEq α]
variable {G : SimpleGraph α} [DecidableRel G.Adj]

prefix:100 "#" => Finset.card
local notation "E" => G.edgeFinset
local notation "d(" v ")" => G.degree v
local notation "I(" v ")" => G.incidenceFinset v

lemma edge_card_eq_two (e : Sym2 α) (he : e ∈ E) : #{v | v ∈ e} = 2 :=
  SimpleGraph.card_filter_mem_of_mem_edgeSet e (by simpa using he)

-- Proof through direct calculation
lemma handshaking : ∑ v, d(v) = 2 * #E := by
  calc  ∑ v, d(v)
    _ = ∑ v, #I(v)                := by simp [G.card_incidenceFinset_eq_degree]
    _ = ∑ v, #({e ∈ E | v ∈ e})   := by simp [G.incidenceFinset_eq_filter]
    _ = ∑ e ∈ E, #{v | v ∈ e}     := Finset.sum_card_bipartiteAbove_eq_sum_card_bipartiteBelow _
    _ = ∑ e ∈ E, 2                := Finset.sum_congr rfl (fun e he ↦ edge_card_eq_two e he)
    _ = 2 * ∑ e ∈ E, 1            := (Finset.mul_sum E (fun _ ↦ 1) 2).symm
    _ = 2 * #E                    := by rw [Finset.card_eq_sum_ones E]
```

What is the policy on when to use implicit arguments? E.g. why is it `card_filter_mem_of_mem_edgeSet (e : Sym2 V) (he : e ∈ G.edgeSet)` and not `card_filter_mem_of_mem_edgeSet {e : Sym2 V} (he : e ∈ G.edgeSet)`?

Also, how do we handle edgeSet vs edgeFinset? Just a separate version for each lemma like `card_filter_mem_of_mem_edgeFinset`?

It probably should be the second one @FordUniver. I put a little bit of thought into binder types, but I wasn't too consistent.

And yeah, the edgeSet vs edgeFinset situation is a need for duplication. (I've never really been happy with the `fooFinset` functions, but people like them for summations, so they've stuck around. By the way, you might like making a `Nat.card` and `∑'` version of your argument, which should let you stick with sets rather than finsets.)

I added `@[simp] lemma toFinset_eq [Fintype α] {e : Sym2 α} : (e : Finset α) = {v | v ∈ e}.toFinset := by ext; simp` to `Mathlib.Data.Sym.Sym2` but needed to import Fintype for that. Is there a more sensible place for this lemma?
Trying to resuscitate this PR. @kmill what is missing to remove the draft label?

pullRequest.title: feat: Sym2-as-Finset theory
